hook.text: A movie ticket cost 25 cents in 1940. Today it costs $12. The movie didn't get 48 times better.

buildup.text: Inflation means the general price level rises over time, reducing what each dollar can buy.

discovery.text: It's not that things get more expensive. It's that money gets less powerful.

twist.text: Moderate inflation is considered normal and even healthy. Economists worry when it disappears.

climax.text: Central banks actually target about 2% inflation per year. Zero inflation isn't the goal.

punchline.text: Rising prices are the plan, not the problem.

quiz.question: What does inflation actually mean?
options: Money loses purchasing power over time

hook.text: The government tracks the price of about 80,000 items every month to calculate inflation.

buildup.text: The Consumer Price Index (CPI) tracks a 'basket' of goods representing typical household spending.

discovery.text: The basket includes food, housing, transport, healthcare, and even haircuts and pet supplies.

twist.text: Your personal inflation rate may differ wildly. If you rent, your inflation is higher than a homeowner's.

climax.text: CPI is an average. Nobody is average. Your real inflation depends on what you actually buy.

punchline.text: Your inflation isn't the headline number.

quiz.question: What does the Consumer Price Index (CPI) measure?
options: Price changes in a basket of typical goods

hook.text: You got a 3% raise this year. Inflation was 4%. You actually got a pay cut.

buildup.text: Nominal values are the raw numbers. Real values adjust for inflation to show actual purchasing power.

discovery.text: A salary of $50,000 in 1990 had the purchasing power of about $115,000 today.

twist.text: Stock market returns look impressive until you subtract inflation. Real returns are much smaller.

climax.text: Always think in real terms. Nominal numbers are misleading without an inflation adjustment.

punchline.text: Nominal lies. Real tells the truth.

quiz.question: What is a 'real' value in economics?
options: The sticker price of an item

hook.text: Your grandparents bought a house for $20,000. That sounds cheap until you adjust for inflation.

buildup.text: Comparing prices across decades without adjusting is meaningless. Dollars change value.

discovery.text: $20,000 in 1960 is equivalent to roughly $200,000 today. The 'cheap' house wasn't so cheap.

twist.text: People nostalgic for old prices forget that old wages were proportionally lower too.

climax.text: What matters isn't the price tag. It's how many hours of work something costs you.

punchline.text: Old prices look cheap. Old wages don't.

quiz.question: Why can't you simply compare prices across decades?
options: The value of money changes over time

topics.title: Why a Little Inflation Is Good

hook.text: Zero inflation sounds ideal. Economists say it would actually be dangerous.

buildup.text: Mild inflation encourages spending and investment. Why hold cash if it slowly loses value?

discovery.text: It also makes debts easier to repay. You borrow today's dollars, repay with cheaper future dollars.

twist.text: Inflation gives central banks room to cut interest rates during recessions. Zero inflation means no room.

climax.text: The 2% target is a buffer â€” enough to keep the economy moving without causing damage.

punchline.text: A little inflation keeps the engine running.

quiz.question: Why do central banks target about 2% inflation?
options: It encourages spending and gives room to cut rates in downturns

hook.text: Too many buyers chasing too few goods. Prices rise because everyone wants the same thing.

buildup.text: When the economy booms, employment rises and people have more money to spend.

discovery.text: If production can't keep up with demand, sellers raise prices. That's demand-pull inflation.

twist.text: Stimulus checks during COVID boosted demand while supply chains were broken. Prices surged.

climax.text: Demand-pull is the most common inflation trigger and usually the easiest for central banks to fight.

punchline.text: More buyers plus fewer goods equals higher prices.

quiz.question: What causes demand-pull inflation?

hook.text: Oil prices tripled in 1973. Suddenly everything made with oil â€” which is everything â€” got expensive.

buildup.text: Cost-push inflation happens when the cost of producing goods rises and businesses pass it on.

discovery.text: Rising wages, raw material costs, or supply disruptions all push production costs up.

twist.text: This type is harder to fight. Raising interest rates slows demand but doesn't fix supply problems.

climax.text: The 1970s 'stagflation' combined rising prices with a stagnant economy â€” cost-push at its worst.

punchline.text: When making things costs more, buying them does too.

quiz.question: What is cost-push inflation?
options: Rising production costs passed on to consumers

hook.text: Print twice the money with the same goods available. Each dollar is now worth half as much.

buildup.text: Milton Friedman said inflation is 'always and everywhere a monetary phenomenon.'

discovery.text: When central banks create money faster than the economy grows, inflation follows.

twist.text: But after 2008, central banks printed trillions and inflation stayed low for a decade. It's complicated.

climax.text: Money supply matters, but so do velocity, expectations, and where the money goes.

punchline.text: More money doesn't always mean more inflation.

quiz.question: Who said inflation is 'always a monetary phenomenon'?

hook.text: If everyone expects prices to rise 10%, they demand 10% raises. Then prices rise 10%. It's a loop.

buildup.text: Expectations are self-fulfilling. What people believe about inflation actually creates inflation.

discovery.text: Central banks spend enormous effort managing expectations through communication and credibility.

twist.text: Once expectations become 'unanchored,' inflation spirals. This is what happened in the 1970s.

climax.text: The Fed's most powerful tool isn't interest rates â€” it's convincing people inflation will stay low.

punchline.text: Believe prices will rise, and they will.

quiz.question: Why are inflation expectations so important?

hook.text: In 2021, a single ship stuck in the Suez Canal disrupted $9 billion in daily trade.

buildup.text: Modern supply chains are global and fragile. A disruption anywhere ripples everywhere.

discovery.text: COVID shut factories in Asia. Demand surged at home. The mismatch sent prices soaring.

twist.text: A semiconductor shortage stopped car production worldwide. Used car prices jumped 40%.

climax.text: Supply chain inflation is different from monetary inflation. You can't fix it by raising rates alone.

punchline.text: Global supply chains are fast but fragile.

quiz.question: What caused the 2021 supply chain inflation?
options: COVID disrupted production while demand surged
Central banks printed too much money

hook.text: In 1923 Germany, a loaf of bread cost 200 billion marks. Workers were paid twice a day.

buildup.text: After WWI, Germany printed money to pay war reparations. The currency became worthless.

discovery.text: Prices doubled every few days. People burned banknotes for fuel because paper was cheaper than wood.

twist.text: The trauma scarred Germany forever. It's why the Bundesbank was obsessively anti-inflation for decades.

climax.text: The crisis ended only when Germany introduced a completely new currency backed by land.

punchline.text: Money can become cheaper than firewood.

quiz.question: Why did hyperinflation strike Weimar Germany?
options: The government printed money to pay war debts

hook.text: Zimbabwe printed a 100-trillion-dollar bill. It couldn't buy a bus ticket.

buildup.text: Land reforms in 2000 collapsed farm output. The government printed money to cover the gap.

discovery.text: Inflation peaked at 79.6 billion percent per month in November 2008.

twist.text: Prices doubled every 24 hours. People spent their pay within minutes of receiving it.

climax.text: Zimbabwe abandoned its currency entirely. People switched to US dollars and South African rand.

punchline.text: When trust dies, the currency follows.

quiz.question: How did Zimbabwe resolve its hyperinflation?
options: Abandoned its currency for foreign ones

hook.text: High inflation and high unemployment at the same time. Economists said it was impossible.

buildup.text: In the 1970s, oil embargoes sent energy prices soaring while economies stagnated.

discovery.text: The Phillips Curve said inflation and unemployment move in opposite directions. Stagflation broke it.

twist.text: Traditional tools failed. Fighting inflation worsened unemployment. Stimulating growth worsened inflation.

climax.text: It took Paul Volcker's brutal interest rate hikes in 1980 to finally break the spiral.

punchline.text: Sometimes the economy breaks the textbook.

quiz.question: What is stagflation?
options: High inflation combined with high unemployment
Rapid economic growth with low inflation

hook.text: Venezuela sits on the world's largest oil reserves. Its people can't afford basic food.

buildup.text: Oil prices crashed in 2014. The government kept spending by printing bolivars.

discovery.text: Inflation hit one million percent in 2018. The currency lost 99.9% of its value.

twist.text: Price controls made it worse. When bread is priced below cost, bakers stop making bread.

climax.text: Millions fled the country. Venezuela shows that resource wealth can't protect against bad monetary policy.

punchline.text: Oil wealth is no shield against bad policy.

quiz.question: What made Venezuela's inflation crisis worse?

hook.text: In 2022, US inflation hit 9.1% â€” the highest in 40 years. Grocery bills stunned everyone.

buildup.text: COVID created a perfect inflation storm: supply disruptions, stimulus money, and pent-up demand.

discovery.text: The debate raged: was it 'transitory' or structural? The Fed initially said temporary. It wasn't.

twist.text: Global factors â€” war in Ukraine, energy shocks â€” added fuel. No single cause explains it all.

climax.text: The Fed raised rates at the fastest pace in decades. By 2024, inflation was falling.

punchline.text: Inflation is never just one thing.

quiz.question: What was the peak US inflation rate in 2022?

hook.text: Inflation punishes savers and rewards borrowers. Your savings shrink while your debts do too.

buildup.text: $10,000 in savings loses purchasing power every year. At 3% inflation, it buys 26% less in a decade.

discovery.text: But a $200,000 mortgage feels lighter over time. You repay with dollars that are worth less.

twist.text: This is why governments with massive debt quietly prefer moderate inflation. It shrinks the debt.

climax.text: The US national debt from WWII was largely 'inflated away' over the following decades.

punchline.text: Inflation is a hidden tax on savers.

quiz.question: Who benefits from inflation?
options: Borrowers, because they repay with cheaper dollars

hook.text: Prices rise, so workers demand higher wages. Higher wages raise costs, so prices rise again.

buildup.text: A wage-price spiral is a feedback loop where inflation feeds itself through labor markets.

discovery.text: In the 1970s, strong unions negotiated automatic cost-of-living raises, locking in the spiral.

twist.text: Breaking the spiral usually requires a recession. Someone has to absorb the pain.

climax.text: Central banks watch wage growth closely. Rising wages are welcome â€” until they outpace productivity.

punchline.text: When wages chase prices, nobody wins.

quiz.question: What is a wage-price spiral?
options: Wages and prices continuously push each other higher
Prices dropping due to wage cuts

hook.text: Your cereal box looks the same. But it now holds 10% less cereal. You just didn't notice.

buildup.text: Shrinkflation is when companies keep the price but reduce the quantity or quality.

discovery.text: Toilet paper rolls got narrower, candy bars got smaller, chip bags got airier. All quietly.

twist.text: It's invisible inflation. CPI doesn't always catch it because the sticker price hasn't changed.

climax.text: Companies use shrinkflation because customers notice price changes but rarely notice size changes.

punchline.text: Same price, less product. Stealth inflation.

quiz.question: What is shrinkflation?
options: Keeping prices the same while reducing quantity

hook.text: Rich people own assets that rise with inflation. Poor people hold cash that loses value.

buildup.text: Stocks, real estate, and businesses tend to keep pace with inflation. Savings accounts don't.

discovery.text: Inflation widens the wealth gap because asset owners are protected while wage earners fall behind.

twist.text: Food and rent inflate faster than luxury goods. The poor face higher inflation rates than the rich.

climax.text: The most regressive tax in the world isn't on any tax form. It's inflation.

punchline.text: Inflation hits the poorest hardest.

quiz.question: Why does inflation widen wealth inequality?
options: Asset owners are protected while cash holders lose value

hook.text: Every time a restaurant reprints menus because prices changed, that's a real cost of inflation.

buildup.text: Economists call these 'menu costs' â€” the expense of constantly updating prices across a business.

discovery.text: It's not just menus. Catalogs, websites, vending machines, and contracts all need price updates.

twist.text: During hyperinflation, some businesses changed prices multiple times per day. The cost was enormous.

climax.text: Digital pricing has reduced menu costs. But the cognitive cost of tracking ever-changing prices remains.

punchline.text: Changing prices costs money too.

quiz.question: What are 'menu costs' in economics?
options: The expense of updating prices across a business
The cost of food at restaurants

hook.text: The most powerful inflation tool is also the most painful: making borrowing expensive.

buildup.text: Central banks raise interest rates to cool demand. Higher rates mean less borrowing and spending.

discovery.text: When mortgage rates rise, fewer people buy homes. When business loans cost more, hiring slows.

twist.text: The medicine works, but with side effects: slower growth, job losses, and possible recession.

climax.text: Volcker raised the US rate to 20% in 1981. Inflation broke â€” but so did the job market.

punchline.text: The cure for inflation is always painful.

quiz.question: How do higher interest rates fight inflation?

hook.text: In 1979, Paul Volcker became Fed chair and did something nobody expected: he crashed the economy on purpose.

buildup.text: US inflation was running over 13%. Previous Fed chairs had been too timid to stop it.

discovery.text: Volcker raised the federal funds rate to 20%. Mortgage rates hit 18%. The economy plunged.

twist.text: Unemployment soared. Farmers drove tractors to the Fed in protest. Volcker received death threats.

climax.text: By 1983, inflation dropped to 3%. The painful medicine had worked.

punchline.text: He broke inflation by breaking the economy.

quiz.question: What did Paul Volcker do to fight inflation?

hook.text: New Zealand invented inflation targeting in 1990. Nearly every central bank copied it.

buildup.text: The idea: publicly commit to a specific inflation target, usually 2%, and adjust policy to hit it.

discovery.text: Transparency builds credibility. If people trust the target, their expectations stay anchored.

twist.text: Before targeting, central banks were secretive. Markets had to guess their intentions.

climax.text: Inflation targeting turned out to be one of the most effective monetary innovations of the century.

punchline.text: Telling people the plan is the plan.

quiz.question: Which country pioneered inflation targeting?

hook.text: Emperor Diocletian set maximum prices in 301 AD. Merchants stopped selling. Shelves went empty.

buildup.text: Price controls cap how much sellers can charge. They sound simple and fair.

discovery.text: When prices are capped below market value, sellers produce less or sell on the black market.

twist.text: Nixon tried price controls in 1971. Shortages appeared. When controls lifted, prices surged higher.

climax.text: Two thousand years of evidence shows the same result: price controls create shortages.

punchline.text: Cap the price, empty the shelves.

quiz.question: What typically happens when governments impose price controls?
options: Shortages appear as producers reduce supply

hook.text: Politicians want low interest rates before elections. Central bankers have to say no.

buildup.text: Independent central banks resist political pressure to keep money too loose for too long.

discovery.text: Countries with independent central banks have significantly lower inflation on average.

twist.text: Turkey's president fired central bankers who raised rates. Inflation hit 85% in 2022.

climax.text: Central bank independence is fragile. It requires political leaders who accept short-term pain.

punchline.text: Independent banks keep inflation honest.

quiz.question: Why is central bank independence important?
options: It prevents political interference from fueling inflation

hook.text: Falling prices sound great until you realize nobody buys anything because it'll be cheaper tomorrow.

buildup.text: Deflation means the general price level is declining. Money becomes more valuable over time.

discovery.text: When people delay purchases, businesses earn less, fire workers, who then spend even less.

twist.text: Debts become crushing. You borrowed $100,000 but now it buys more â€” and you still owe every dollar.

climax.text: The Great Depression featured severe deflation. Prices fell 25% in four years.

punchline.text: Falling prices can freeze an economy.

quiz.question: Why is deflation dangerous?
options: People delay spending, creating a downward spiral
Prices become too low for stores

hook.text: Japan spent nearly 30 years battling deflation. Prices barely moved. Neither did the economy.

buildup.text: After a massive asset bubble burst in 1991, Japanese consumers stopped spending.

discovery.text: Falling prices led to falling wages, falling confidence, and more falling prices. A deflation trap.

twist.text: The Bank of Japan cut rates to zero. It wasn't enough. They eventually went negative.

climax.text: Japan's experience terrified other central banks and shaped the aggressive COVID-era stimulus.

punchline.text: Once deflation takes hold, escape is hard.

quiz.question: What happened to Japan after its asset bubble burst?

hook.text: Your TV costs half what it did five years ago. That's deflation â€” but the good kind.

buildup.text: Technology-driven price drops come from better productivity. More output for less cost.

discovery.text: When prices fall because supply improves, that's healthy. When they fall because demand collapses, that's trouble.

twist.text: Electronics, solar panels, and computing power all show good deflation. Economies benefit from it.

climax.text: The key distinction: good deflation comes from innovation. Bad deflation comes from despair.

punchline.text: Not all falling prices are equal.

quiz.question: What distinguishes 'good' deflation from 'bad' deflation?
options: Good comes from innovation; bad comes from falling demand

hook.text: Every hyperinflation in history ended one of two ways: new currency or new government.

buildup.text: When inflation spirals beyond control, the existing currency becomes worthless.

discovery.text: Germany created the Rentenmark. Brazil created the Real. Zimbabwe adopted the US dollar.

twist.text: The new currency only works if people trust it. Trust requires credible institutions and fiscal discipline.

climax.text: Brazil's Real Plan of 1994 worked brilliantly. A new currency with credible backing ended decades of chaos.

punchline.text: To fix money, sometimes you replace it.

quiz.question: How do countries typically end hyperinflation?
options: By introducing a new, credible currency

hook.text: The coffee that cost $1.50 five years ago now costs $3. You're watching inflation in real time.

buildup.text: Everyday prices are the most visible sign of inflation, but they're also the most variable.

discovery.text: Gas, groceries, and rent change faster than electronics, clothing, or services.

twist.text: Your personal inflation rate depends on your specific spending mix â€” and nobody else has the same one.

climax.text: Tracking your own expenses over time reveals your true inflation rate, not the headline CPI number.

punchline.text: Your inflation is personal.

quiz.question: Why might your personal inflation rate differ from the official CPI?
options: CPI reflects average spending, not your specific purchases
